verses.text: Afterward, Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘Let My people go, so that they may hold a feast to Me in the wilderness.’”
verses.comment: Moses and Aaron deliver God’s command to Pharaoh, initiating the Exodus narrative. The mention of a feast foreshadows Israel's worship and sacrifice, reminiscent of future liturgical celebrations (see Lev. 23).

verses.text: But Pharaoh replied, “Who is the LORD, that I should obey His voice and let Israel go? I do not know the LORD, and moreover, I will not let Israel go.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s refusal displays his spiritual blindness and resistance to God. Throughout Scripture, hardness of heart symbolizes rejection of divine authority, paralleling opposition to Christ’s claims (see John 12:40).

verses.text: Then they said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us go a three-day journey into the wilderness to sacrifice to the LORD our God, or He may strike us with pestilence or with the sword.”
verses.comment: Sacrifice in the wilderness demonstrates the importance of right worship. The request shows obedience to God’s specific command and the underlying fear of divine judgment for neglect—echoing the biblical call to prioritize worship.

verses.text: But the king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why are you taking the people away from their work? Get back to your labors!”
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s focus is on economic productivity above spiritual needs, reflecting a worldly mindset. This contrast highlights the tension between temporal concerns and obedience to God’s will.

verses.text: Pharaoh also said, “Look, the people of the land are now many, and you are making them rest from their burdens.”
verses.comment: The multiplying of Israel fulfills God’s promise (Gen 12:2, Exod 1:7), even as it incites oppression. The mention of rest foreshadows the Sabbath principle, central to biblical worship and communal life.

verses.text: That same day, Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters of the people and their overseers,
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s swift response escalates the persecution, matching patterns of oppression seen throughout Scripture when God’s people are about to be delivered (see Dan. 3:19-20).

verses.text: “You shall no longer give the people straw to make bricks as before; let them go and gather straw for themselves.”
verses.comment: Increasing the burden without providing means is a classic element of tyrannical rule. Symbolically, suffering prepares God’s people for redemption, a theme fulfilled in Christ’s Passion.

verses.text: But the number of bricks they made previously, you shall impose on them; you shall not reduce it. For they are idle; therefore they cry, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to our God.’
verses.comment: Pharaoh misinterprets the Israelites’ desire for worship as laziness. The retention of requirements despite worsened conditions emphasizes the seeming impossibility of salvation under mere human power.

verses.text: Let heavier work be laid on the men, that they may labor at it and pay no regard to lying words.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh calls God’s words lies, a pattern seen throughout salvation history where worldly powers reject divine revelation (see Matt. 28:11-15).

verses.text: So the taskmasters of the people and their overseers went out and spoke to the people, saying, “Thus says Pharaoh: ‘I will not give you straw.’”
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s word is set against God’s word, echoing later biblical conflicts between obedience to earthly and heavenly authority.

verses.text: ‘Go, get straw wherever you can find it, but your work will not be reduced in the least.’”
verses.comment: The heightened struggle for resources intensifies the hardship, setting the stage for God’s intervention. It teaches perseverance amid unjust demands.

verses.text: So the people scattered throughout all the land of Egypt to gather stubble for straw.
verses.comment: Israel’s suffering under forced labor echoes the spiritual need for deliverance, with gathering stubble highlighting futility apart from divine aid.

verses.text: And the taskmasters pressed them, saying, “Complete your work, your daily amount, as when there was straw.”
verses.comment: Persistence in oppression is contrasted with God’s coming mercy. It prefigures the persistence of sin’s burden, only overcome through grace.

verses.text: Moreover, the Israelite overseers, whom Pharaoh’s taskmasters had set over them, were beaten and asked, “Why have you not finished making your quota of bricks yesterday and today, as before?”
verses.comment: The suffering of innocent overseers reflects the cost of unjust systems. It foreshadows Christ’s own suffering and intercession on behalf of His people.

verses.text: Then the Israelite overseers came and cried out to Pharaoh, saying, “Why do you treat your servants this way?”
verses.comment: Their appeal to Pharaoh for mercy is met with indifference, teaching reliance on divine deliverance, not merely worldly powers—a theme emphasized in New Testament teachings (see Luke 18:1-8).

verses.text: No straw is given to your servants, and yet they say to us, ‘Make bricks!’ We are beaten, but it is your own people who are at fault.”
verses.comment: The overseers point out the injustice, highlighting the futility of seeking fairness from those who reject God’s truth, a lesson seen throughout biblical history.

verses.text: But Pharaoh said, “You are idle, idle! That is why you say, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to the LORD.’
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s repetition of ‘idle’ discloses his spiritual ignorance and his prioritization of labor over worship—a point of contrast with later calls to sanctify time for God (see Heb. 4:9-11).

verses.text: So go now and work, for no straw will be given you, yet you must deliver the same number of bricks.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s command is inflexible and punitive, echoing humanity’s bondage under sin before redemption.

verses.text: The Israelite overseers saw that they were in trouble when they were told, “You must not reduce your daily amount of bricks.”
verses.comment: Recognition of their plight brings Israel to despair—a situation that often precedes God’s deliverance (see Ps. 34:18; 2 Cor. 1:8-10).

verses.text: When they left Pharaoh, they met Moses and Aaron, who were waiting for them.
verses.comment: Moses and Aaron's presence reflects God’s ongoing care and leadership, prefiguring later spiritual guidance and intercessory roles in the people’s journey.

verses.text: And they said to them, “May the LORD look on you and judge, because you have made us detestable in Pharaoh’s eyes and in the eyes of his servants, and you have put a sword in their hand to kill us.”
verses.comment: The people blame Moses and Aaron for their suffering, showing human tendency to doubt God’s plan under hardship. Ultimately, God will vindicate His servants and deliver His people.

verses.text: Then Moses turned to the LORD and said, “O Lord, why have You brought trouble on this people? Why did You send me?”
verses.comment: Moses’ honest prayer displays authentic relationship with God. Doubt and struggle in faith are normative, and calling out to God leads to deeper trust—a spiritual principle present in the psalms and the life of Jesus (see Matt. 27:46).

verses.text: For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has done evil to this people, and You have not delivered Your people at all.”
verses.comment: Moses voices frustration at seemingly unanswered prayer. This developmental faith journey highlights perseverance. Deliverance often follows periods of intensified suffering, foreshadowing the pattern of death and resurrection in the Christian mystery.
